Subjective: Dizziness x3 days, started upon waking. Room spinning (vertigo) with some light-headedness. Worsens with head movement, better when sitting still. Mild nausea, heart palpitations during dizzy spells. Impact: Stops patient from doing much. Negatives: No vomiting, no headache, no hearing problems (loss, ringing), no speech difficulties, no limb weakness/loss of function, no fainting. Recent: A bit of a cold. Social: No smoking, no alcohol, no drugs. ICE: Scared it's serious (friend had brain tumor), wants to get rid of dizziness, wants to know cause.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/70, Pulse 62 bpm. Neuro: Face sensation symmetrical, facial movements normal. Shoulder shrugs normal. Arms: No drift on 'tray' test, finger-to-nose normal bilaterally. Legs: Knee lifts normal, heel-to-buttock normal bilaterally. Gait: Normal, tandem gait normal. Eye movements: Smooth pursuit normal, no nystagmus on visual tracking. HIT: Negative bilaterally. Dix-Hallpike maneuver: Right side provokes intense vertigo, nausea, and nystagmus. Left side provokes less intense vertigo.
Assessment: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). Ruled out: Brain tumor, central neurological deficit.
Plan: 1. Explanation: BPPV due to displaced vestibular crystals, not brain tumor. Can resolve spontaneously. 2. Treatment: Perform Epley maneuver in clinic. 3. Instructions: Provide instructions for self-Epley maneuver via thuisarts.nl.
